Episode.Title: He Shall, From Time To Time...

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. PRESS BRIEFING ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and his staff are preparing for the State of the Union address. The President, from behind the podium, reads the speech from the TelePrompTer.

Dialogues.Line: With nearly 18 million new jobs, wages rising at more than twice the rate of inflation, the highest home ownership in history, the smallest welfare rolls in 30 years and the lowest peacetime unemployment since 1957. [beat] I stand before you to report that America has created the longest peacetime economic expansion in our history. For the first time in three decades, the budget is balanced. From a deficit of 290 million dollars just ten years ago...
Billion dollars. Toby interrupts the President. Leo is seated beside him.
You said million, but let's move on.
[clears throat] From a deficit of 290 billion dollars, just ten... it says 'million' on the TelePrompTer, by the way.
Sam? Sam is behind them controlling the TelePrompTer with several White House staffers.
L-Let's take it back. The President coughs hard. He is sweating, and he looks tired.
Mr. Speaker, Mr. Vice President... Behind all of them, Josh and C.J. are watching the President from a television.
Members of the 106th Congress, distinguished guests...
You know what I forgot to do today?
I forgot to feel the President's glands.
Do you think the joke reflex you use as a defense mechanism is why you have so much trouble keeping a man?
I'm saying, we're 44 hours away from the State of the Union, and he doesn't look so good. Bartlet continues to read from the TelePrompTer.
...And how do we make the American dream of opportunity a reality for all? I came to this hallowed chamber one year ago, and I see we're spelling 'hallowed' with a pound sign in the middle of it.

I came to this hallowed chamber one year ago on a mission: to restore the American dream for all our people, as we gaze at the vast horizon of possibilities open to us in the 321st century... Wow, that was ambitious of me, wasn't it?
I'm proud to report our country's stranger than it was a year ago?
Taking care of it. [leaves] Josh and C.J. approach the President. Bartlet and his staff start to walk away.
Why is everyone asking me that today?
But you don't look so good.
I'm fine. They walk out to the HALLWAY.
You should be taking something, sir.
I don't know. My wife hands me pills. I swallow them with water.
Vitamin C. Vitamin B. Is it possible I'm taking something called 'euthanasia'?
Ah, that sounds more like it... Toby?
Are you actually taking them, or are you just carrying them around in your pocket?
[beat] You know, carrying them around in my pocket was a pretty big step for me.
You got to take the pills.
'How do we make the American dream a reality for all who work for it.'
You got to add, 'who work for it.'
We've decided this two weeks ago.
We've seen some pretty compelling polling samples. We need 'people who work for it' and I'll tell you what else.
'The era of big government is over.'
This morning, we had a meeting.
We decided to offend poor people?
The people we're offending won't be watching the State of the Union.
Yeah, I can't imagine why not. The group continues to walk. They stop around the corner of THE OVAL OFFICE.
It's what they're listening for in welfare reforms, so screw it.
Alright, but when you get visited in the middle of the night by the ghost of Christmas future, don't come running to me.
Damn, Toby, 'cause you're exactly who I was gonna come running to.
Well, I'm gazing in the 321st century, man. There's a lot on my mind.
Let's finish up in here. [indicates the Roosevelt Room]
Oh, dear God. I will take the pills, C.J.
Yes. I will go to the Oval Office, and pour a glass of water from the Steuben glass pitcher, which was a gift from the Christian Charity Network there, Skippy.
I'm just saying, before you start calling me, Ebenezer Bartlet, remember, I got a really nice glass pitcher for just, you know, being a good guy.
Well, you turned me right around on that one, Mr. President.
[waves the bag of pills in the air] I will take the pills. Bartlet goes inside THE OVAL OFFICE and closes the door. Sam, Leo, Toby, Josh, and C.J. are left standing outside.
Technically, the Speaker of the House invites the President to deliver the State of the Union.
And we haven't been invited yet?
Good, cause you know, we want to be able to report that the country's a lot stranger than it was a year ago.
I'll never be able to live it down.

No. Leo and C.J. laugh. CRASH! The staffers heard the sound of broken glass from inside THE OVAL OFFICE. They quickly go inside. We see the President lying face down unconscious in his carpet. Beside him is the broken Steuben glass pitcher and the spilled water. We hear a Secret Service Agent.
Liberty's down. We're in the Oval.
Get a doctor. Some of the group try to feel the President's pulse from his neck.

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Bartlet has regained consciousness. He is seated in a chair. The physician on duty, ADMIRAL HACKETT,  has just taken his temperature. The staff is around them.

Dialogues.Line: Well, his temperature's 101.9. I'm fairly sure he's got the flu, but I want to take him to Bethesda for a cardiogram.
I didn't have a heart attack, Leo. I got the flu, and I don't need a cardiogram.
I also want blood work and a chest x-ray.
No, I think it's the flu, but I don't want to fool around.
Leo, I'm fine. Mrs. Landingham approaches. She gives him a piece of paper with a note on it.
Thank you, Mrs. Landingham... Mrs. Landingham how do I look to you?
You're a very handsome man, Mr. President.
Uh, it can wait till morning, but I want to stay with him for an hour or two.
Do the blood work, send it to the lab, get the cardiogram and chest x-ray tomorrow.
Situation Room. [gives Leo the note, which he reads]

Alright, let's do this, and then you're going to bed. [to Hackett] We'll meet you in the residence in a few minutes. The President stands up. He gets dizzy again and almost falls down. Everyone tries to grab him.
You're a real cut-up there, Mr. President.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE SITUATION ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff are inside, including the chairman, Admiral Fitzwallace. They are waiting for the President.

Dialogues.Line: I'm gonna tell him 'steady and not egregious, sir.' We're all okay with that?
We got the 2nd, 3rd, the 103rd, the 106th, and the 107th.
Thank you. The double doors open. In comes Bartlet, followed by Leo. The Joint Chiefs of Staff all stand up.
Anybody know if the Celtics won tonight?
We can get that information, sir. [signals an officer to go to the phone while all sit]
Sir, there's been steady but no egregious clashing along the cease-fire line. If you look at the photo-recon analysis, you'll see India has moved new units into their four structures at the border.
It was a two-week cease-fire. There's four days left.
What's Intel saying about the Pakistanis?
They're desperately concerned that if the Indians continue their offensive, they won't be able to defend the capital with conventional forces.
Is this just whining or it's for real?
Bazin's given command control of some of their nuclear weapons to field commanders in theater, but I think they're just trying to get our attention.
Sir, I'm gonna scramble the B-1's out of Manila, and put the 49th tactical on recon on ready alert.
I'm going to bed. But somebody call me if there's movement.
Yes, sir. Bartlet and Leo head for the door. The officer just got off the phone.
Thank you, Mr. President. Bartlet and Leo leave.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Mandy and Danny are inside.

Dialogues.Line: So, I grow the rest of the beard back?
C.J., don't you think Danny looked very cute with the full beard?
I actually never thought about it.
Actually, I came by to see my fish.
The fish is fine, and I need my office.
[dryly] He gave me a fish a few weeks ago... that one there. [looks at Gail]
C.J., it wouldn't kill you to be a little friendlier to him.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo comes in. Margaret follows him.

Dialogues.Line: I thought it was a Constitutional requirement.
Then why do we have to be invited?
It dates back to Parliament! What do you want from me?
Also, remind Josh to pick a guy.
He's in bed. Hackett's up there with him.
She cancelled her trip. She's on her way from Andrews.
Yeah, it's on the Internet right now.
Why don't we do a preemptive...
You'll talk to the press in the morning?
I'm gonna work with you first, okay?

Okay... [looks for a second] Okay. [leaves] CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - NIGHT Bartlet is sitting up in his bed talking on the phone. Admiral Hackett prepares for a blood test as Charlie stands watch.

[into phone] It tested very well. I'm not saying we're doing it, Toby. I just want to try it and see how it reads. The era of big government is over... All right. Thanks. Bartlet hangs up the phone. He folds his arm when Hackett finished the blood test.
I'm feeling roughly the same as I was feeling when you asked me four minutes ago.
It's okay. This isn't the worst of it, Charlie. The worst of it's coming up the stairs right now. On cue, the bedroom door opens. Abbey comes in.
[puts her jacket and bag on a chair] Hey, Charlie. How you doing?
Ma'am, I'm Admiral Hackett. I was on duty when it happened. [offers hand]
[shakes hands] Good to meet you, Admiral. Charlie, would you mind getting my bag please? Charlie does. Abbey takes a clipboard from Hackett. The President tries to get her attention.
When's the last time you checked?
The pressure dropped before he fainted, but it's coming back.
I want to put him on an IV/saline and vitamin solution. [to Jed] Honey, you still dizzy?
I was wondering when you were gonna notice me.
He's lying. Give him Flumadine, 100 milligrams, twice a day.
Thank you, admiral. Would you mind waiting outside for a minute?
Thanks, Charlie. [pause] Charlie, would you mind waiting outside for a minute?
No, ma'am. Do you need anything?
No, thanks very much. Charlie leaves and closes the door.
You're very sexy when you're in doctor mode you know that? Give me an IV/saline solution and 100 milligrams of Flumadine. Stat. [beat] I could jump you right now.
I could kill you right now.
[checks his eyes] It took you 25 minutes to call me.
Fitzwallace called me in the Situation Room. There was more movement in Kashmir.
I don't care if Canada invaded Michigan, Jed. You call me.
I broke the Steuben glass pitcher in the Oval Office.
You could've hit your head on something. [gives her husband an injection]
[quietly] Was it like the time in Nantucket?
Or was it like the time at my parents?
It's all right. Close your eyes. You're gonna be asleep in a minute. Abbey takes the pillow from behind Bartlet, who lies down.
Fitzwallace says the Pakistanis are giving command control to some nuclear weapons to the field.
It's okay. Leo's in the West Wing.
I'm really sorry about the pitcher.
I could jump you right now.
Yeah, sure you could. Bartlet falls to sleep. Abbey, fighting back tears, sits on a chair and looks around the room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh is talking on the phone.

Dialogues.Line: [into phone] I don't think it's being sorted in the mailroom. It's an invitation to the President to address Congress. I'm assuming it was hand-delivered. [listens] Thank you. Donna knocks at the door.
Yes. Josh goes out the door into his BULLPEN AREA. Donna follows.
She said Leo said to remind you you need to pick a guy.
She said you'd know what that means.
Do you know what that means?
I don't know what that means.
Someone from the line of succession is required to be absent from the State of the Union.
Wait, I know why. They walk to the NORTHWEST LOBBY.
So if somebody blows up the building, nobody's...
Who do you think I should pick?
I think you should pick me.
And where exactly do you fall in the line of succession?
If somebody blows up the Capitol Building, I'd imagine I'd move up a few slots.
Fair point. They open the door to a HALLWAY.
Yes. [stops] Listen. Be sweet to Margaret and Leo today. This might not be the worst day of their lives, but it's got to be in the top five.
See ya later. Donna goes the other way. Josh continues walking.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh comes in and closes the door. Leo is reading a speech that was prepared. They're rehearsing for his press conference. Sam and C.J. are seated on the couch.

Dialogues.Line: I deeply regret the pain and trouble this has caused for the people in my life...
When you left Sierra Tucson, did you start attending meetings?
Don't say A.A. if they don't say A.A.
[sits] When you left Sierra Tucson, did you start attending meetings?
Yes. C.J., Sam, Josh are surprised.
How about as often as I need to?
The President and I have a long history and a close personal friendship...
The President has known, as well as the FBI and the Secret Service.
Did they raise any objection to a man with your problem in such a sensitive position?
Yeah, they were concerned I'd sell state secrets to Bolivia for a quick...
It's not a totally unreasonable question.
Okay. Leo goes to his desk. Sam, Josh and C.J. stand and get ready to leave.
Uh, Leo, I wrote a draft to the President's statement of support. I thought you might want to...
I wrote a draft to the President's statement of support.
Who told you to do that?
[yells] I know what conditions he's in. I'm asking who told you to write a statement of support?
Toby told him last night to...
Nobody had to tell me. You're about to get attacked. It's what I do.
No, your job isn't to protect me, Sam. It's to protect the President.

Do me a favor, Sam. Don't show initiative. Don't rush to my defense. I don't want to see you on Crossfire. I don't want to see you on Larry King. I don't want to read your name in Newsweek unless it's an advocacy of the President's agenda. [calms down] I go down, I go down. I'm not taking anyone with me... Is that clear?
I'm all set. Go back to work.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet, now awake, sits up on his side of the bed still in his pajamas. Abbey, all dressed up, is seated beside him and has just finished taking her husband's temperature.

Dialogues.Line: Well, the good news is, your temperature's gone down.
Can I go to the office?
It hasn't gone down enough, and it's gonna go back up again.
'Cause you have the flu. Abbey takes her stethoscope and puts the end on the President's back. She listens.
Here's the thing though. I never really saw you study while you were in med school.
Do you even know what you're listening for right now? [inhales]
Do you know how many other people I could have married?
Okay. Bartlet takes off his blanket and tries to stand up. Before he could, he realizes he's still dizzy and sits back down.
Alright. I think I'll stay here for a little bit.
Okay. The President puts back his blanket.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is waiting just outside the briefing room. Carol opens the door.

Dialogues.Line: No. Leo goes into the PRESS BRIEFING ROOM. The reporters are on their seats. Cameras flash. Leo steps behind the podium.

A story, in which many, if not most of you, are aware of already, will break in wide circulation by the end of the day. I'd like to take this opportunity to read a brief statement before I answer your questions. [starts reading] In June of 1993, I voluntarily admitted myself to the Sierra-Tucson Rehabilitation Facility to treat an addiction to alcohol and Valium. [looks up, cameras flash from everywhere] I am a recovering alcoholic and drug addict. [looks up again] I deeply regret the pain and trouble this has caused for the people in my life. I'd like to, at this point, clarify a few things...

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: INT. HALLWAY - DAY
Scenes.Description: Donna and Josh are walking.

Dialogues.Line: I don't know why you're picking the secretary of agriculture.
Because the secretaries of defense, state and treasury are famous faces, and we want the camera to find them.
So, if the Capitol Building blows up...
The man my country will be looking to is the secretary of agriculture.
Which is why I really don't care that much.
Donna, I really don't anticipate the Capitol Building exploding.
What percentage of things exploding have been anticipated?
I read the statement you wrote for the President--sensational, Sam. I'm sorry no one's gonna read it.
The President's gonna read it. He's reading it right now.
Nah. We pan to THE ROOSEVELT ROOM. Toby is having a meeting with RAYMOND BURNS and two other Congressmen about the State of the Union address.
Toby, I'm concerned that the speech contains a number of positions that democrats and Congress aren't quite on board with yet.
They're free to write they're own speech.
I understand, but they are the ones who are gonna have to run against us a year from now.
We feel, even in this draft--
Yes, but even in this draft, there's too much emphasis placed on the role of federal government.
This is an opportunity for a pep rally. This is an opportunity to trumpet government. Why do we want to pretend to be sorry for intruding?
Because that's what people want to hear.
Why don't' you pick your section of the speech. Fight with me about it, and I'll lose, and then I can call in the next group.
Pick a section. There's a line waiting outside. I've got 31 hours to-to write this...
The N.E.A.? [sighs] Let us open our hymnals to page 22. The Congressman smiles.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is reading a piece of paper. The television on his right broadcasts his press conference. He looks at himself for a brief moment. He turns the TV off with a remote control before Margaret walks in.

Dialogues.Line: You told me your press conference was gonna be this afternoon.
I told you that I didn't know...
No, it's not. Mom and I should have been there.
Oh, yes, definitely a picture of me standing next to my estranged wife--
I don't want to fight with you.
I saw a copy of the President's statement.
For the press, supporting you. It's-it's floating around.
It's very moving, dad. He loves you so much.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam talks to a staffer. Josh comes up from behind.

Dialogues.Line: We're getting slapped around on the N.E.A.
Oh, man! Why is he...? They go into SAM'S OFFICE.
I mean N.E.A. is putting up a fight... Leo walks in. He's angry.
I understand you're being pissed off--
What, you're giving me Abbott and Costello?

They want to tear you down, plain and simple. They don't like you and this is what they do, and for us not to defend you? I disobeyed you. I apologize, but that's the way it is. Behind Leo, Bonnie just got off the phone.
The First Lady's in your office.
Thank you. [to Sam] This is not what I wanted. [walks away]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Abbey is joking with Mallory.

Dialogues.Line: You've got an itch for Sam Seaborn.
I do not have an itch.
Want a nickel worth of free advice?
Don't go for the geniuses. They never want to sleep.
Oh, Leo, hi. I'm sorry. I hope I didn't take you away from something.
Oh, no, no, no. Mallory, would you mind...?
I do not have an itch!
[kisses Leo] Bye daddy. Mallory leaves and closes the door. Abbey shifts to the couch.
Mallory was very proud of you.
Leo, I came by because I wanted to ask do you think there's a huge downside to postponing for a few days?
Did the fever go back up?
What should I know that I don't know?
I just thought we should be on the safe side.
Because that President has a temperature. The President's not in nursery school.
Look, if it's a problem to postpone--
It's not a problem to postpone. Of course, I wouldn't do anything to jeopardize the President's health. What I'm saying...

[sits] Hey, hey, hey. This is me. This has happened before. I see you trying to cover the panic. I see you prescribing medication. I think you're giving him shots. What does he have he can't tell people?
Ugh! You would not have come back for the flu, Abbey.
He fainted. He was running a fever.
Abbey? A pause. Almost in tears, Abbey decides to tell him the truth.
A fever could be life threatening. Abbey tries hard to fight back tears, but couldn't. A tear falls from her eye.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: The television is on. A soap opera playing.

Dialogues.Line: Mrs. Crane, there are some things you mustn't say to Chief Bennett. He's married to someone else and so are you. Bartlet is in bed eating breakfast. Charlie is seated on a chair.
I don't understand. Don't any of these characters have jobs?
I don't know, Mr. President. I think one of them is a surgeon.
They seem to have a lot of free time in the middle of the day. The phone rings. Charlie answers it.
And that woman's changed her clothes for quite a lot in one afternoon.
[hangs up] Mr. President, Mr. McGarry's outside.
Yeah. Would you mind stepping out, Charlie?
No sir. [leaves] Bartlet turns the T.V. off. Charlie closes the door when Leo walks in. Leo walks over to the President.

Abbey phoned me up and told me about your conversation. I was diagnosed about seven years ago. My life expectancy is normal. My particular course of MS is relapsing-remitting, which means I should experience total recovery after attacks. Abbey gives me injections of something called Betaseron, and that reduces the frequency. Fever and stress tend to be two things that induces attacks.

Well, you're the President of the United States, you're delivering the State of the Union tomorrow night, India and Pakistan are pointing nuclear weapons at each other, and you have a 102-degree fever. So I guess we're out of the woods, hmm?
Jed, of all the things you could've kept from me...
You haven't called me 'Jed' since I was elected.
'Cause I wanted to be the President.
That wouldn't have stopped me from getting you here. And I could've been a friend.
But when it was time to really...
When I was lying on my face in the motel parking lot, you were the one I called.
When you stood up there today, I was so proud. I wanted to be with you.
I tried to get up, but I fell back down again.
[fights back tears] I'm so sorry, Leo. I really am.
Yeah, give us a minute, would you please?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE ROOSEVELT ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby is still in his meeting.

Dialogues.Line: Now, the President's proposing in his speech that the budget by the N.E.A. be increased by fifty percent?

The National Endowment amounts to less than 1/100th of one percent of the total budget for the federal government. It costs taxpayers 39 cents a year. The arts budget for the U.S. is equivalent to the arts budget of Sweden.
That is such a big deal being made out of the performance arts of the Mapplethorpe photographs--
Well, once again, all we'd like is for you to not mention the N.E.A.

Personally, I don't know what to say to people who argue that the N.E.A. is there to support art that nobody wants to pay for in the first place. I don't know what to tell people when they say Rogers and Hart didn't need the N.E.A. to write Oklahoma, and Arthur Murray didn't need the N.E.A. to write Death of a Salesman.

I'd start by telling them that Rodgers and Hammerstein wrote Oklahoma, and Arthur Murray taught ballroom dance, and Arthur Miller did need the N.E.A. to write Death of a Salesman, but it wasn't called the N.E.A. back then. It was called W.P.A. and it was Roosevelt's... [long pause] It was Roosevelt's...
You stopped talking in the middle of a...?
Thank you everybody. This meeting is over. Toby leaves. The congressmen looked surprised.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Bartlet and Leo are settled on the couch. Lord Marbury is across them.

Dialogues.Line: You know, there are some marvelous flu remedies known in the certain remote parts of the subcontinent. Licorice root, for instance, combined with bamboo sap and a strong shot of whiskey. Ginger root, also, mixed with, uh, citrus peel.
And a strong shot of whiskey?
Yes, of course. In fact, you can throw out the ginger root and citrus peel, and still be well in your way.
What have you got for me, John?
Well, um, after speaking at length this past week with your secretaries of state and defense, as well as your joint chiefs and various embassy officials, I believe this. Buy them off.

Mr. President, for several centuries, my kingdom has ruled India with a stick and carrot. When we had a particular problem with someone, one solution we would try is to make him a maharaja. That's kind of a regional king. We would pay him off with an annual tribute, and in return, he would be loyal to the crown.
Lord Marbury, under our Constitution, our President is not empowered to create maharajas.
Yes. Thank you for clearing that up, Leo. Having been educated at Cambridge and the Sorbonne, I am, as you know, exceedingly stupid.

You've been paying the world off since the industrial age. Foreign aid, during the Cold War was you paying dictators to be on your side. To this very day, you pay Korea not to develop nuclear weapons.
A computer industry, and for that, they require an infrastructure, and that is what you can give them.
For avoiding a war halfway around the world?
For being rich, free and alive all at the same time, and for the criminally negligent behavior of your Congress in not checking the proliferation of nuclear devices.
All right, you tell the ambassador we'll discuss this in three months. In three months, John. I don't want this to be like quid pro quo.
That's the carrot. Leo, what's the stick?
In the next 24 hours, we want to see recon photos of Indian divisions retreating. If we don't, we're gonna seize Indian assets and so will our NATO allies, and G-7's gonna call in its loans.
They put command-control in the field, John, and we're gonna get physical. You make damn sure they know that.
Well, then, uh, I have my instructions. The three of them stand.
Talk to the ambassador. I want Fitzwallace to have photos in 24 hours.
I'm gonna go back to the office.

You know, I was watching a television program before with a sort of a roving moderator who spoke to a seated panel of young women who are having some sort of problems with their boyfriends. Apparently, because the boyfriends have all slept with the girlfriend's mothers. Then they brought all the boyfriends out and they fought right there on television. Toby, tell me, these people don't vote, do they?
I wouldn't think so. No sir.
[pokes his head in] Excuse me, Mr. President.
I asked Josh to join me here, sir.
The era of big government is over.
You want to cut the line?

I want to change the sentiment. We're running away from ourselves, and I know we can score points that way. I was the principle architect in that campaign strategy, right along with you, Josh. But we're here now. Tomorrow night, we do an immense thing. We have to say what we feel. That government, no matter what its failures are in the past, and in times to come, for that matter, the government can be a place where people come together and where no one gets left behind. No one... gets left behind, an instrument of... good. [pause] I have no trouble understanding why the line tested well, Josh, but I don't think that means we should say it. I think that means we should... change it.
I think so, too. [beat] What do you think, Josh?
I'd make it a point never to disagree with Toby when he's right, Mr. President.
Then you and Sam get your people together and get to work.
Thank you. Toby and Josh leave.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT

Dialogues.Line: Everyone is waiting for the State of the Union address. Josh, Sam, and C.J. are having a conversation.
[sing-song] You're jealous 'cause Danny was flirting with Mandy.
I didn't say that. When did I say that?

You know, C.J., it can be pretty confusing sometimes. I mean I'm at this place with Mallory, where I don't know if she likes me. I don't know if she doesn't like me. I don't know if she's indifferent altogether. I just wish she'd take the bull by the horns and get past it so we can move on. Across the room, Mallory finds Sam.
Sam! Did you write this statement defending my father?
Uh, yes. Mallory walks over to Sam and kisses him. She pulls back then kisses him again, this time longer than the first. Josh and C.J. just stare at them. Mallory walks away after the kiss.
Well, now I'm even more confused.
Though, I gotta say, I'm enjoying being a writer. C.J. looks around the room. She sees Carol.
Carol, is Danny Concannon in the Press Room?
Would you have him come to my office, please? C.J. smiles as CAROL walks away.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Abbey is going over the speech. Bartlet goes over to his wife and watches as she buttons his sleeve.

Dialogues.Line: I want to take your temperature one last time.
I want to take your temperature.
You've taken it 14 times in the last three hours. You're not taking it again.
At least not with a thermometer.
I'm saying if you want to take it recreationally...
Oh, there's something wrong with you, you know that?
Why is 'hallowed' spelled with a pound sign in the middle?
I stopped asking those questions. Bartlet takes off his wife's glasses and kisses her.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. C.J.'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Danny is playing with Gail while waiting for C.J. Someone knocks at the door.

Dialogues.Line: Right. [opens the door and comes in] Hello.
So... you have asked me out many times. I have said no.
Nonetheless, I do seem to have a preoccupation, um, sort of girlish, I suppose, thing, which, um... and please don't be in any way mislead by anything... in fact, let me put it this way...
C.J., I'm gonna write about the speech tonight. My paper's gonna want to, you know, see it. Is there any way we can move this along?
I thought what I'd do is kiss you, you know, on the mouth, then I'd just get past it... I'd just get past it, and I'll be able to give my work the kind of concentration it really deserves.
No, I'm saying cause if you rock against the... Danny grabs C.J. and kisses her.
Okay, I got to go now. [takes Gail with her and heads out]
No. She puts the fishbowl back on the table and heads out. She bumps into the door.
Yes. C.J. opens the door, walks out. She flashes a very big smile.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE MURAL ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Abbey and Lord Marbury are among the many people in the room. They go to the door.

Dialogues.Line: Uh, see, you're too fixed on western medicine. Bamboo sap, gambeer twig...
And a shot of whiskey in the old sense. Abbey laughs. They see Bartlet and Leo walking in. They all stand by the door.
Good evening, Mr. President. Bartlet gives him several photographs.
[goes over the pictures] Uh, well now, if I'm not mistaken, these are photos of Indian troops retreating, and so is that, and so is... this.
Well, I'm on a plane to go see Rikki in an hour... still many things to settle.
Thank you sir. They shake hands.
Good luck to you too, Leo. Leo shakes hands with Marbury.
I am off! [walks away] Bartlet, Abbey, and Leo step inside THE MURAL ROOM.

Friends, let me have your attention please. A lot of time, energy, passion, wit, skill, and talent went into drafting this, and while you might not know it from my delivery later, this is an extraordinary speech. And I say thee yea! Toby Ziegler, and I say thee yea! Sam Seaborn! Everyone in the room clap their hands for the President's speechwriters. Charlie comes in and informs the President.
Sir, the motorcade's ready and the agriculture secretary is in the Oval Office. Bartlet nods. Everyone is still clapping for Toby and Sam.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. OVAL OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Charlie opens the door from outside. Bartlet walks in. The secretary of agriculture, ROGER TRIBBY, is standing in the middle of the room.

Dialogues.Line: Roger, I'm sorry you drew the short straw on this. We'll miss you tonight. Next year, it'll be the surgeon general, I promise. Meanwhile, you can watch TV at my study.
Thank you, sir. [beat] Um, I brought you a gift. [offers him a book]
I know of your love of all things ancient, and I came across this.
Someone took the time to translate the Constitution into Latin. I think it was a high school project, actually, and uh, it got published.
I highlighted what I thought was an appropriate passage from the executive power section. Can you translate?
[reads] 'He shall, from time to time, give to the Congress information on the state of the union and recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient.'
Sounds right up your alley, sir.
Knock 'em dead, sir. Bartlet heads to the door. He stops as he remembers something.
Oh, Roger, if anything happened, you know what to do, right?
I honestly hadn't thought about it sir.

First thing always is national security. Get your commanders together. Appoint joint chiefs. Appoint chairman. Take them to Defcon 4. Have the governor send emergency delegates to Washington. The assistant attorney general is gonna be the acting A.G. If he tells you he wants to bring out the National Guard, do what he tells you. LEO'S OFFICE. As Bartlet tells Tribby the procedure, we see Leo walk into his office to get his coat. The door to the Oval Office is open so he can hear the President and Tribby, but couldn't see them.
Would you trust him with your life?
That's your chief of staff. Leo, obvioiusly touched, stops for a minute and walks away. Back in THE OVAL OFFICE, Charlie walks in. Bartlet continues to speak.
Oh, in the residence, in the second floor, the bathroom at the end of the hall. You have to jiggle the handle a little.
I got to go. [beat] You'll do fine. People have phenomenal capacity.

Yes, sir. Bartlet holds his book and puts his fist against his chest close to the heart. Tribby stands watch as the President and Charlie leave. After they've gone, Tribby is standing in front of the Presidential seal and looks around the Oval Office in awe.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
